My statement on the House Armed Services Committee’s markup of the #FY20NDAA. It’s a good bill for our district and our nation. Read more below: https://garamendi.house.gov/media/press-releases/garamendi-secures-wins-climate-change-military-housing-and-more-national …
Thank you for following along. I hope you learned something new about our government. Feel free to comment with any questions.

I think the amended text made the bill even stronger. It’s now up to us as members of the Armed Services Committee to educate our fellow Reps on this bill and why, in my opinion, it deserves strong bipartisan support when the full House votes on it. #FY20NDAA.

And in case you were wondering, I voted for the bill. It passed by a bipartisan vote of 33-24 in committee. I thought the base text of the bill took the necessary measures to keep us safe, care for our service members, and take bold action to address things like climate change.

After 21 hours of work, the #FY20NDAA has passed the Armed Services Committee. It’s been a pleasure walking through this process with you. Please feel free to comment with any questions you may have. Next, the bill will be voted on by the full House of Representatives.
We are still taking votes in the full House. We will return to the Armed Services Committee to complete the #FY20NDAA markup upon completion of these votes.

We are now in recess while we take votes in the full House of Representatives. We will reconvene following these votes to finish the #FY20NDAA markup.

As we enter hour 12, it is clear to see the Representatives are working hard on this #FY20NDAA. However, the incredible work that each Rep's staff puts in is not always known or recognized and I would like to take a moment to thank them for their work.

We've now moved on to the final stage of the NDAA markup: the full committee mark. The issues we'll cover under this section do not fall under the jurisdiction of any of any subcommittee. It's the final stage, but we still have a lot of issues to cover.

The Strategic Forces Subcommittee mark is now wrapping up. It took longer than the other subcommittee marks because there were more individual amendments introduced that had to be debated and worked out. We didn't used the en bloc process as often.

@MacTXPress, the top Republican on the committee, said “He likes round numbers, so that's how $750 [billion] got there.”

So this is something to keep an eye on as we continue to work through the #FY20NDAA this evening.

The President called for a $750 billion top-line even after 23 of 26 Republicans on the Armed Services Committee sent him a letter supporting the $733 billion funding level. Why did he do this? #FY20NDAA.

Now we are expecting it to be a contentious issue during the markup. So what changed? Once again, the President threw a wrench into an issue with bipartisan support. The President did that here by asking for a higher top-line funding level. #FY20NDAA.

It's the sum of every authorization we fund in the entire bill. Right now the top-line funding level is $733 billion--which is exactly what the DOD planned and asked for. Our friends on the other side of the aisle also agreed with that funding level: https://turner.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/turner-leading-house-members-in-urging-trump-to-uphold-733b-for-dod-in …

We are in another recess and will reconvene in a few moments. It gives me the time to highlight something that will likely come up throughout the hearing: the total funding level in this bill, otherwise known as the "top-line" funding level. #FY20NDAA.

The en bloc package has passed and my two bills have made it into the mark! This is a common method Reps use to move legislation. Attaching individual bills to much larger legislative packages, like the NDAA, gives those bills a greater chance of passing Congress. #FY20NDAA.

We have included all other amendments with broad bipartisan support into the Intelligence and Emerging Threats and Capabilities Subcommittee mark through the en bloc process. We've voice voted the mark and are moving on to the next subcommittee's mark.
In this instance it was because the amendment required a waiver from another committee to be considered, but the other committee did not grant the waiver.

This amendment was withdrawn due to what's called a point of order. Points of order are prohibitions against certain types of legislation or congressional actions. These prohibitions are enforced when a Rep raises a point of order against legislation that may violate these rules

Now, as we work through the Intelligence and Emerging Threats and Capabilities Subcommittee markup, we have our first individual amendment that we will consider. When individual amendments like this are proposed the full committee debates it and oftentimes votes on it.

Voice voting is the quickest way to vote on something because we don't have to tally each Rep's vote. It's typically used when there's broad consensus on a vote or issue. It is the right of any Rep to request a recorded vote even if a voice vote is proposed.
En bloc is when we bundle noncontroversial amendments together and vote on them all at once. The Chair of the subcommittee provides an overview of the en bloc package before we vote on it.

The language for the TAL has been amended and adopted. It was a very quick process for this subcommittee's mark because it had broad bipartisan support and noncontroversial amendments. Because of that, the committee adopted the amendments en bloc and voice voted the mark.
Here is the full markup language for the Intelligence and Emerging Threats and Capabilities Subcommittee: https://armedservices.house.gov/press-releases?ID=71DE56B7-49D0-450D-8EF7-A161D91169B7 …

Now we are reviewing and amending the subcommittee markup for the Intelligence and Emerging Threats and Capabilities Subcommittee. Here's an overview of the subcommittee and its jurisdictions:  https://armedservices.house.gov/emergingthreatsandcapabilities …

^this sounds complicated, but think of it as individual chapters within a full book. We are reviewing and editing the TAL Subcommittee's chapter (their markup) to the full book (the NDAA). Members will try to edit the chapter before it's in the full book by introducing amendments

Here is the full text of the TAL's markup for the billthat we are discussing, amending, and then formally adopting into the NDAA (one of the things you learn quickly as a member of this committee is that you have to memorize a ton of acronyms): https://armedservices.house.gov/press-releases?ID=D37F7FC6-5809-4031-A8B4-C7B5D97843AA …

Now we are amending and voting on the subcommittee mark for the Tactical Air and Land Forces (TAL) Subcommittee. Here's an overview of what's under TAL's jurisdiction:  https://armedservices.house.gov/tacticalairandlandforces …
Right now the Chairman of the Committee, Adam Smith (D-WA), is providing an overview of the process and delivering his introductory remarks.
